fields.template_text: Your BMI is {bmi}. Aim for a gradual 5–7% weight loss by adopting a balanced calorie-controlled diet and at least 150 minutes of moderate exercise per week.
Your fasting glucose is {blood_glucose_level} mg/dL. Reduce simple sugars—choose whole grains and high-fiber foods to help stabilize blood sugar.
Staying hydrated supports glucose regulation. Aim for at least 8 cups (≈2 L) of water daily, and limit sugary or caffeinated beverages.
Regular cardio helps improve insulin sensitivity. Start with 30 minutes of brisk walking or cycling, 5 days a week.
Including resistance training twice weekly can build muscle mass and support glucose control—try bodyweight exercises or light weights.
Add flexibility exercises like yoga or stretching at least 3 times a week to improve overall mobility and reduce injury risk.
Smoking increases diabetes complications. Consider nicotine replacement or counseling—many programs offer free support lines.
Good sleep habits support insulin sensitivity. Aim for 7–9 hours nightly: keep a regular schedule and reduce screen time before bed.
Chronic stress can raise blood sugar. Practice relaxation techniques—try 5 minutes of deep breathing or mindfulness daily.
Consider tracking your meals with a food diary or app to identify high-calorie patterns and maintain portion control.
Swap one refined starch (white bread, pasta) per day for a whole-grain alternative to help reduce post-meal glucose spikes.
Break up long sitting periods: stand or walk for 5 minutes every hour to boost circulation and glycemic control.
Avoid heavy meals and caffeine within 3 hours of bedtime to promote more restful sleep.
Incorporate a short daily walk in nature or with a friend to lower stress hormones and improve mood.
Consider starting each meal with a glass of water to help control appetite and support hydration.
